quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Start by assuming you no longer have product market fit, because you had product market fit in a different market.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical reset mindset for adapting marketing strategy when macro conditions change.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's a different market now, so you have to start over.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A blunt mental model that pushes teams to re-validate fundamentals instead of making incremental tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: But if you just assume you need to launch a new channel to fix this problem, you're going to be wrong, because your entire customer base changed, not just the next 10% of customers that you're looking for.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that reframes “channel problems” as customer/market shift problems.

quotes.topic_title: Improv experience and career phases
quotes.text: I mean all of them. I just embrace what gets thrown at me and allow it to organically happen.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A mindset for navigating career phases by leaning into uncertainty rather than over-optimizing for a single “best” stage.

quotes.topic_title: Improv experience and career phases
quotes.text: And so made a pretty conscious choice early on that it was more of a hobby and if something ever came of it, cool, but if not, that's okay.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical approach to balancing passion pursuits with career stability—commit consistently without forcing monetization.

quotes.topic_title: Improv experience and career phases
quotes.text: It's something I keep coming back to, because it's very grounding and fulfilling in ways that work and family life and things like that don't quite hit for me.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Highlights the value of maintaining an “off-axis” activity that meets psychological needs your main roles may not satisfy.

quotes.topic_title: Improv experience and career phases
quotes.text: So, I think generally the whole suite of skills that you develop in improv are pretty applicable, right? Because you are getting comfortable on your feet with change, with teamwork, building off of each other, experimenting, trying new things, a little bit of everything.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A transferable-skills framework: improv as training for adaptability, collaboration, and rapid experimentation at work.

quotes.topic_title: Improv experience and career phases
quotes.text: which is in a scene the worst thing you could do is deny somebody, because you're actually just stopping progress and you're not building off of anything.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Actionable collaboration advice: avoid “denial” behaviors that halt momentum; build on others’ contributions to keep progress moving.

quotes.topic_title: Improv principles applied to business collaboration
quotes.text: So, the appropriate approach is to say, "Yes, that is true, and..." and add to it.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable collaboration framework for progressing ideas instead of blocking them.

quotes.topic_title: Improv principles applied to business collaboration
quotes.text: The other one that I think is less known or talked about is the gift of details.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Introduces a lesser-known improv principle that translates into clearer communication and better problem framing at work.

quotes.topic_title: Improv principles applied to business collaboration
quotes.text: But if I say, "We create content that is both education and entertainment to solve people's deep curiosities in the way that maybe a biography would." That just opens up the exact problem that you're trying to solve.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Shows how adding specific details sharpens positioning and makes the underlying customer problem easier to reason about.

quotes.topic_title: Improv principles applied to business collaboration
quotes.text: It's like, oh, both of these things can be true at once.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical mental model for cross-functional conflict: accept competing local vs central realities to unlock progress.

quotes.topic_title: Improv principles applied to business collaboration
quotes.text: I think it's still a really great class to take, even if you have zero interest in doing improv, or public speaking, or any of that kind of stuff.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice that reframes improv as a general professional skill-builder, not a performance hobby.

quotes.topic_title: Why teams should take improv classes
quotes.text: My wife actually, she's a designer, artist, writer, illustrator kind of person, and she's been taking a lot of these sorts of classes to help inspire her creativity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of using classes (like improv/standup) as a repeatable practice to spark creativity and idea generation.

quotes.topic_title: Why teams should take improv classes
quotes.text: One is how to decide when to invest in an emerging acquisition channel like TikTok, VR, Clubhouse was a big thing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical growth decision area—timing investments in emerging channels—anchored with specific channel examples.

quotes.topic_title: Why teams should take improv classes
quotes.text: To the growth CMR role, which is kind of this, I think emerging role, something you're really good at, and I just want to get your thoughts on what's happening there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to an emerging organizational role in growth and invites analysis of how responsibilities and impact are evolving.

quotes.topic_title: Why teams should take improv classes
quotes.text: And then, three, some real talk on burnout and depression that often comes with working in tech and stuff that we go through.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Surfaces a high-signal, often under-discussed operational reality that affects team performance and sustainability in tech.

quotes.topic_title: Framework for evaluating emerging acquisition channels
quotes.text: So, the exploring emerging channels framework that I'll take, either my teams or companies that I'm advising through, has three core ingredients that I like to spend time with.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Introduces a structured, repeatable framework for evaluating whether to invest in an emerging acquisition channel.

quotes.topic_title: Framework for evaluating emerging acquisition channels
quotes.text: So, the first is really understanding if there is an overlap between what the customers need is, what your company's goals are, and what the channel actually does really well.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical screening test to decide if a channel is even worth experimenting with before spending cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Framework for evaluating emerging acquisition channels
quotes.text: And so it's like what are the strengths of that channel is something that... that is actually probably the piece I see people ignore the most, which is they just want to know if a channel is hot or not.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder to prioritize channel strengths/fit over hype when choosing new growth bets.

quotes.topic_title: Framework for evaluating emerging acquisition channels
quotes.text: And part of this reason is to accept the risks of going into that channel. So, if I go and dedicate two quarters of work to Clubhouse, I need to accept that they are so early in this curve that there's a good chance this is a once in a lifetime opportunity and it'll be over. It's not a repeatable action.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A concrete risk model for early channels: time investment can be non-repeatable and may vanish quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Framework for evaluating emerging acquisition channels
quotes.text: But then Facebook just pulled the plug on that. And so it's like, well, if you put all of your energy into that and that's it, it was pretty clear that that was still an area that's like this may not last forever.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Specific example showing platform dependency risk: a channel can disappear overnight, so avoid over-concentration.

quotes.topic_title: How to test new channels effectively
quotes.text: But generally speaking, I think keeping it minimum at first is my typical recommendation.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A clear rule of thumb for resourcing new-channel experiments: start with minimal investment until you see signs of traction.

quotes.topic_title: How to test new channels effectively
quotes.text: Generally I wouldn't let anything bleed past a quarter.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A concrete timebox to prevent channel tests from dragging on without decisive learning or progress.

quotes.topic_title: How to test new channels effectively
quotes.text: You can probably get some good signal in a month or less, what I would call fishing.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for early-stage channel testing focused on finding signal before optimizing for statistical certainty.

quotes.topic_title: How to test new channels effectively
quotes.text: But ideally what you're working through, and we'll touch a little bit more on this with the Growth CMO, is that this should all be part of a roadmap. It shouldn't just be randomly chosen and thrown at.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Emphasizes that channel experiments should be planned within a roadmap/backlog to manage opportunity cost and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: How to test new channels effectively
quotes.text: Yeah, and I think define that going into it. What am I looking for, for this?
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical methodology: pre-define success signals (often qualitative or directional) before running the test.

quotes.topic_title: Promising channels: OTT, influencers, VR, podcasts
quotes.text: So, I mean I mentioned OTT, or basically the key thing with OTT is that it's way more trackable than traditional television, but it has similar value that traditional TV does in terms of the ability to do more long form storytelling type content, and a lot of it's not skippable if you buy it.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical rationale for testing OTT: combines TV-style storytelling with better measurement and less skippability.

quotes.topic_title: Promising channels: OTT, influencers, VR, podcasts
quotes.text: It's also got that hyper granularity that when I get into influencer tools, it feels to me like early Facebook when I used to go be able to target Lenny, or 10 people that have exactly the same likes as Lenny.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: influencer tooling can recreate “early Facebook” precision targeting as major platforms become less open.

quotes.topic_title: Promising channels: OTT, influencers, VR, podcasts
quotes.text: It's incredibly tedious and manual and it's a lot of relationship management. So, I'm also keeping an eye on the technology being built around influencer, because I think that's a huge area of opportunity for entrepreneurs right now.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Highlights the operational bottleneck (manual relationship work) and where tooling can unlock scale—useful for both marketers and builders.

quotes.topic_title: Promising channels: OTT, influencers, VR, podcasts
quotes.text: And actually what I keep seeing as the effective strategy with podcast ads is treating them more like radio where it's more about getting on the right program, making it personal and feel like it should be part of that program, and then repeating over and over and over again.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Counter to “podcasts as direct-response”: the playbook that works is contextual fit + host-read personalization + repetition.

quotes.topic_title: Promising channels: OTT, influencers, VR, podcasts
quotes.text: So, I think podcast is super interesting. I think it's just hard to scale. It's likely not going to get people the same volumes as the Googles and Facebooks of the world.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A clear scaling constraint to set expectations and channel-mix decisions: podcasts can work, but won’t match platform-level volume.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, we've always thought of Amplitude as being about supporting the full product loop. Think collect data, inform bets, ship experiments and learn. That's the heart of growth to us.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Provides a clear end-to-end growth framework teams can use to structure analytics and experimentation work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, the big aha was seen how many customers were using Amplitude to analyze experiments, use segments for outreach and send data to other destinations. Experiment and CDP came out of listening to and observing our customers.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product strategy: expand capabilities by observing real customer workflows and adjacent use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I also come from a very consumer perspective. I'm actually stronger on B2B companies using podcasting, because it has that exact same value I just described, but each one of their customers is substantially more valuable. So, they don't need the scale that a consumer application or product would need.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive channel insight: B2B can justify podcasting with lower scale because customer value is higher.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channel hit rate and influencer tools
quotes.text: Like 5% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A concrete hit-rate benchmark for how often truly emerging channels pay off, useful for setting expectations and resourcing.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channel hit rate and influencer tools
quotes.text: I think the area that I think of as emerging that I've found more success in is taking things that exist already and make them... so the two slices of it are either it's existed for a long... like podcasting. So, it existed for a long time and now we're finally getting to a spot where it feels scalable. The other is existing channels that introduce something brand new.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical framework for “emerging channels” that are more likely to work: newly-scalable old channels or existing channels with new capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channel hit rate and influencer tools
quotes.text: But brand spanking new channels, I don't know, they rarely work or are worth the effort early that you hope that they will be.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A counterintuitive caution against chasing brand-new channels too early, even when they feel exciting or high-upside.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channel hit rate and influencer tools
quotes.text: That being said though, like I said, it's still super manual.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A grounded reality check on influencer tooling: platforms help, but the operational workflow still requires significant manual effort.

quotes.topic_title: Crossing the chasm and shifting product-market fit
quotes.text: What I see missed a lot of the time that I like to spend time with people on is to really understand that those early adopters are often just drastically different than the broad audience.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Highlights the core mental model that early traction may not translate because early adopters can be fundamentally unlike mainstream users.

quotes.topic_title: Crossing the chasm and shifting product-market fit
quotes.text: And spending time to actually figure that out and map out what you need to see with those early adopters to have confidence that the product is actually going to have product market fit beyond them.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to define explicit evidence/criteria from early adopters that de-risks crossing the chasm.

quotes.topic_title: Crossing the chasm and shifting product-market fit
quotes.text: it's probably the biggest flag that I see with a lot of companies that claim to have product market fit, which is your TAM and your product market fit are not using the same definition.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A diagnostic red flag: teams often talk about a big market while proving PMF in a different, narrower market definition.

quotes.topic_title: Crossing the chasm and shifting product-market fit
quotes.text: I think that's another piece of it is that the audience changes aren't always just literal people.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that “audience” can shift due to context (e.g., economy), not just demographics or segments.

quotes.topic_title: Crossing the chasm and shifting product-market fit
quotes.text: Start by assuming you no longer have product market fit, because you had product market fit in a different market. It's a different market now, so you have to start over.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical reset framework for market/economic shifts: re-validate PMF before scaling or changing acquisition strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Growth CMO role
quotes.text: One of the key examples I like to use is brand, in that everybody when they think about brand they think of it as an action, not as a consistent ongoing investment, or they think about it as campaigns and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Reframes brand from one-off campaigns to an ongoing investment, changing how teams plan and resource brand work.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Growth CMO role
quotes.text: And in my mind, I think a Growth CMO is looking at each brand investment as how do you then immediately follow that up with the next one? How do you shift to this fast product iteration mindset with even things like brand?
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Defines a Growth CMO mindset as building compounding iteration loops—even for brand—rather than treating marketing as discrete launches.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Growth CMO role
quotes.text: That, to me, means that we have a lot of mismatch marketing leadership, and that quickly eliminates trust with the marketing organization.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Highlights the organizational cost of hiring traditional CMO profiles into product-led contexts: rapid trust erosion and execution friction.

quotes.topic_title: Defining the Growth CMO role
quotes.text: But I think product driven companies, product led companies, if you are CMO and your product leader aren't married at the hip, you're just missing out on just tons of opportunity, and the likelihood of things actually working very well consistently and compounding on each other.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Actionable operating principle: tight CMO–product leadership coupling is required to unlock compounding growth in product-led companies.

quotes.topic_title: Growth CMO attributes: data, agility, experimentation
quotes.text: And so when we take things like retention and even brand and the consideration funnel and, yes, you can't measure those exactly like you can measure landing page clicks and sales, but you absolutely can measure them.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Reframes “performance” marketing to include measurable brand and retention work, pushing practitioners to instrument the full funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Growth CMO attributes: data, agility, experimentation
quotes.text: But having that more of a agile type approach to everything.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: Advocates applying agile iteration not just to campaigns but to all marketing surfaces and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Growth CMO attributes: data, agility, experimentation
quotes.text: All of those things, like being more open to everything being possibly iterated on, on a regular basis using data to validate that and challenge what has worked for you.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A practical methodology: treat every element (including brand) as testable, and use data to continuously challenge legacy winners.

quotes.topic_title: Growth CMO attributes: data, agility, experimentation
quotes.text: If you as a marketing leader aren't being iterative and thoughtful about things with it, you'll get eaten alive.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A blunt warning that modern product-driven markets punish slow, non-iterative marketing leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Growth CMO attributes: data, agility, experimentation
quotes.text: And in my mind, the world that we live in now, product is no longer a part of marketing, but it's actually they're married at the hip. They're one and the same, and most companies aren't operating that way.
quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.context: A counterintuitive operating model: marketing and product should function as a single integrated system in modern software companies.
